basics.name: Omid Vaheb
basics.label: ML Engineer / Applied Scientist
basics.summary: Detail-oriented Applied Scientist specializing in scalable ML models for cross-functional engineering solutions.

work.name: REDspace
work.summary: Improving ASR pipeline accuracy by reducing Word Error Rate and hallucination errors, leveraging contextual data within Mockingbird AI dubbing product.
highlights: Applied OpenAI Whisper model and developed a multimodal error correction solution.

work.name: Vector Institute
work.summary: Collaborated with Vector staff to deliver deep learning solutions addressing AI needs of SMEs.
highlights: Mastered RAG and LLM fine-tuning & alignment.

work.name: University of Toronto
work.summary: Developed an unsupervised training framework for astronomical image denoising.
highlights: Achieved 15dB PSNR improvement and reduced observation costs by 66%.
Decreased memory usage by 80%, reducing execution time up to 60%.

work.name: National Research Council Canada
work.summary: Lowered MAE in astronomical image reconstruction by 15% using Restormer transformer and UNets.
highlights: Created large-scale synthetic data using real galaxy simulations.

work.name: Computational Audio-Vision Lab
work.summary: Developed deep learning models for Autism detection in infants using crying audio.
highlights: Achieved 92% accuracy using deep networks and ensemble techniques.

work.name: Virasad Startup
work.summary: Developed real-time anomaly detection and forecasting models for production lines.
highlights: Used LSTM and ARIMA for time series forecasting.

volunteer.summary: Lead organizer for the New York City branch of the People's Climate March, the largest climate march in history.
highlights: Awarded 'Climate Hero' award by Greenpeace for my efforts organizing the march.
Men of the year 2014 by Time magazine

education.area: Electrical Engineering, Minor in Computer Engineering

awards.title: Nobel Prize in Physics
awards.summary: The Nobel Prizes are five separate prizes that, according to Alfred Nobel's will of 1895, are awarded to 'those who, during the preceding year, have conferred the greatest benefit to humankind.'

references.name: Prof. Stark Draper
references.reference: My mazing supervisor during my master's studies. Professor @ ECE at UofT
